node.text:
🍣 SUSHI WITH KIDS // Before you scroll past this post, because you think making sushi with your kids is too hard, STOP! 🛑 Let me tell you, it is totally doable and the results are deeelicious! 🤩 We used @gimmegrams sushi nori, which is restaurant-quality and organic! 🤤 Just watch the full video 📹 to see my 3 year old in action, and read on below👇 for the step-by-step instructions and some tips to make things as easy as possible! 🙌
-
💚 Sponsored 💚 
-
HERE’S WHAT YOU NEED
• 2 cups sushi rice cooked, we made ours in an instant pot!
• Rice Vinegar
• Sugar
• Salt
• gimMe Sushi Nori
• Sesame Seed
• Avocado
• Cucumber
• Imitation Crab
-
HOW TO
(1) Season the sushi rice to taste, we added about 1/4 cup vinegar, 1/2 tsp sugar, and 1 tsp salt;
(2) On top of a rolling mat, place one sheet of gimMe Sushi Nori (rough side up!);
(3) Spread the sushi rice on top in an even layer. (Wet your hands as needed!)
(4) Sprinkle sesame seeds on top of the rice;
(5) Flip the rice-covered nori over;
(6) On top of the nori, arrange slices of avocado, slices of cucumber, and imitation crab, leaving 1 inch of rice from the bottom.
(7) Roll the mat over, keeping the filling in place with your fingers, so that you make a tight log!
(8) Remove the rolling mat, and (grown ups!) use a sharp, wet knife to slice into pieces.
-
TIPS
• PREP THE MATERIALS: Having the items prepped will make the process run so much smoother.
-
• STICKY SOLUTION: The very nature of sushi rice is that it is sticky! Have plenty of dish towels and a bowl of water nearby to reset clean hands!
-
• SLICING THE SUSHI: My 3yo tried slicing the sushi with his kid-friendly knife, but it was not sharp enough to do the job! So have a grown-up do this part!
-

node.text:
If you have a picky eater (or as I like to say, a selective eater), then you know introducing new or different foods can be a challenge! 😅 But, oh. my. gosh! 😍 Here is an activity, that brought the fun back to our kitchen table! 🤩 We approached this experiment-style, noting exposure to a new food through sight, feel, and ultimately taste! 👅 I gave my selective eater 4 new foods to explore —  @gimmegrams seaweed, kiwi, pan de yuca, and sautéed carrots — and his exploration of each was absolutely amazing! 🙌 I’d love to know whether you’ll try this too! Or if you know a friend who this activity might benefit, be sure to share it with them! 👌 Any questions at all? Drop👇 them in the comment section below, or DM me!
-
#gimmepartner #gimmeseaweed
-
#activitiesforkids #kidfood #playideas #sensoryplay #sensory #ot #occupationaltherapy #kidapproved #funfood #whatifeedmykid #momlife #foodforkids #kidsfoodideas #feedingkids #kidsfood #toddlerfood #eeeeeats #kidfoodideas #kidfriendlyfood #toddlermeals #food #kidfriendly #snackideas #pickyeaters  #yummy #toddler  #parenting #toddlerlife

node.text:
This diy counting board is the perfect tactile resource for early math learning! 🤩 The removable cards and moveable wooden beads are perfect for some hands on fun. 🙌 While this craft certainly takes a little more effort to create than most of our activities, the good news is, it is a resource we come back to time and time again! 👌 Plus, it is super adaptable for children at different math levels as you can add as many beads as you like! 👍 Read on below👇for the how-to and if you have any questions at all, send me a direct message!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• 2 pieces of identical Cardboard, and additional cardboard for number cards
• Twine or thick string
• Beads
• Glue
• Hole punch
-
HOW TO
(1) Using a sharp knife, cut out 2 rectangular shapes on one of the cardboard pieces. This is where the number cards will go.
(2) Then cut out a thin, long rectangle below. This is where the tactile counting beads will go.
(3) Punch a hole on each end of the rectangle;
(4) Tie a piece of twine through one hole securely;
(5) Thread the beads onto the twine and secure the beads by tying the other end to the hole;
(6) Glue the 2 cardboard pieces together, with the beads and cut out pieces on the top;
(7) Take scrap cardboard, and cut out rectangle shapes for the number cards;
(8) On each rectangle, write each number. If counting to 20, you’ll need two 1s. If counting to 30, you’ll need an additional two 2s, and so forth. Now the board is ready for some serious counting fun!
-

node.text:
This DIY shape matching game is a fun way for kids to learn shapes! 🔻🔸▪️ Bonus points for making this so you don't lose the puzzle pieces. 🙌 The best part about this easy shape activity is that it is fast and simple to make. Read on below 👇 for the easy steps if you want to make it too!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
Pieces of Cardboard
Shapes to trace (or an excellent eye for hand drawing them!)
Marker
Paint Sticks
String
Velcro Circles
-
HOW TO
(1) Cut out shapes from a piece of cardboard.
(2) Color the shapes - a fun, bonus, art activity for kids!
(3) Trace the shapes on a sheet of cardboard - this will be your puzzle board.
(4) Stick down velcro stickers on the board and on each puzzle piece.
(5) Attach the shapes to a string so that they don't get lost.
(6) Let the kids have a blast matching the shapes.
-

node.text:
Here’s a fun way to celebrate birthdays, play dough style! 🥳 If you’ve been following along, we love making play dough kits, and this one takes the cake (pun definitely intended 🤣). Play dough kits are easy to make and super convenient to have on hand - say if it's a rainy day or you simply need a fast-to-set-up quiet time activity! 👌 And one of our favorite things to do with play dough kits is to give them as gifts! 💝 Read on below 👇 for our easy no-cook play dough recipe, and make sure to save this post so you remember to find it in the future! 
-
p.s. these are not real sprinkles! We used rainbow rice, but you can also get fake sprinkles which are even better since they don’t bleed the color into the dough!
-
NO COOK PLAY DOUGH RECIPE
Mix Together
• 1 1/4 cup of all-purpose flour
• 1/3 cup of fine salt
• 2 tablespoon of cream of tartar
• 2 tablespoon coconut oil (optional)
Add
• 3/4 cup of boiling water (I mix in food coloring to water prior to heating water up in microwave).
• I wear gloves and mix the *very hot* play dough by hand to make sure that the dough is kneaded thoroughly, which spreads the heat, dissolving the granules to make a smooth texture.
Note
*If too sticky add a little more flour
*If too dry add a little more water
*Coconut Oil gives the play dough a super silky texture. You could also use glycerine. Alternatively, other vegetable oil will work too, but I’ve found that coconut oil makes it super silky!
*Cream of Tartar is a preservative, it makes the play dough have a longer shelf life.
-

node.text:
Look, we aren’t afraid of real mud, 😆 BUT a taste-safe alternative for young kids does not disappoint! 🙌 It’s such a great sensory experience that can also really strengthen fine motor skills if you throw in some tongs! 💪 Save this post so you remember to try this easy 3-ingredient recipe - all the details on how you can make it too are below.👇 And share this with a friend who might want to try it too! 💕
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
* 1 Cup Corn Starch
* 1/4 Cup Cocoa Powder (or brown food coloring)
* About 1/2 Cup of Water
* Washable Toys like bugs, dinosaurs, or farm animals
* Tools (spoons, bowls, tongs)

HOW TO
(1) Mix together the corn starch and cocoa powder.
(2) Add the water in slowly. You may find that you need less or more than 1/2 cup of water. The consistency you want is hard enough to make the oobleck turn into a solid when squeezed in your fist, but when you relax your hand it will turn into a liquid. Add more water if too dry, add more corn starch if too liquidy.
(3) Grab some washable toys, tools, and a bucket of water for kiddos to clean off their hands!
-

node.text:
This interactive arts and crafts project is a fun way to enjoy the colors of the changing seasons! 🍁 #ad My Florida kids don’t get to see the beautiful leaves that fall during Autumn, so this was the perfect way to talk about how green leaves 🍃 can turn to brown, red, orange, and yellow during this time of the year! 🍂 From the paper, to the paint brushes, oil pastels, and paints, all our supplies came from the @michaelsstores Creatology collection. They truly gave this project the deep, rich, colors of the Autumn season! 🤩Highly recommend stopping by Michaels whenever you are in need of kids craft supplies! 🙌 Save this post so you remember to do it later. All the details on how you can make this are below! 👇 Oh, and if you need a leaf template, head to my link in bio for our free printable! 👌 
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• Fall Leaf Template
• Mixed Media or Watercolor Paper
• Oil Pastels
• Green Acrylic Paint
• Paint Brushes
• Coin
-
HOW TO
(1) Print out an Autumn leaf (free printable available at 7daysofplay.com)
(2) Use oil pastels to color the leaf in Autumn colors - like brown, orange, and red!
(3) Cover the leaf with green acrylic paint
(4) Once dried, use a coin to scratch way the green paint to reveal an Autumn leaf!
-
#MakeItWithMichaels
-

node.text:
Popping onto your feed to share this beautiful reminder about not only how unique each and every child is, but also the power YOU hold in amplifying their one-of-a-kind voices. 📣 Here’s to grown ups who support their kiddos no matter how unexpected their songs might be! 🎉 If there is one thing I’ve learned as a parent, it’s that adaptability is key. Before kids, I surely knew exactly how things would go right?! WRONG! 🤣 I am smart enough now to know that I knew nearly nothing before! 🤦‍♀️ Nah, instead of preconceived ideas of how this whole parenthood thing plays out, embrace those twist and turns. 🤗 Listen to the beat of your child. 🎶 Because that melody may be new, different, and better than anything else you could have dreamed of! 💕
-

This easy coloring sheet is super simple to set up! 🙌 It is such a creative and relaxing activity, perfect for after school or quiet time! 🧘‍♀️ There is something so inviting about a huge coloring page with lots of supplies to explore! 🎨 There are so many ways you can adapt this activity based on what you have available! @anideaontuesday was definitely my inspiration for this activity - they have so many ideas for setting up huge, table-length invitations to create like this!

node.text:
Did you know that before the store-bought Mr. Potato even existed, it was very common for kids to make Mr. Potato Head at home using a potato and kitchen scraps? 🥔🤩 Yup! It's a classic. There are so many reasons to love this activity, but one of the highlights is that it exposes kids to fruits and veggies that they may or may not already love. 🙌 For those with picky eaters (like me!), exposure is critical and one of the ways to get kids comfortable with foods they may not love is through touching, exploration, and play. 💪
-
However, we definitely do not want to promote food waste, so this activity should be super adaptable. 👌 Take a few days to save up some food scraps - you know, the trimmings and bits and pieces that would otherwise end up in the trash bin! ♻️ Got some blueberries that are getting too soft to eat? Use them! Eating some carrots, but don't need the leafy ends? They can make great hair! 🥕 And the list goes on and on! Oh, and when finished with all that fun play, eat the potatoes! 🥔 They'll have enough holes in them that they will be sure to boil and soften quickly! 🤣
-

node.text:
Transforming homemade play dough into vibrant swirls is so easy and fun! 🤩 Save this post so you remember to do it too! 🙌 And if you are looking for a quick and easy play dough recipe that will last, read on below 👇 for my how-to and tips!
-
Tips for Making the Perfect Batch
-
Wear gloves while mixing the water! The mixture will be very hot so protect yourself with gloves and keep the kiddos away!
-
Why is my batch too sticky? Too much water was added! If too sticky add a little more flour.
-
Why is my batch too dry? Not enough water was added! If too dry add a little more water.
-
Do I need to add oil? The coconut oil gives the dough a super silky texture.
-
What is cream of tartar, and do I need it? The cream of tartar is a preservative and it makes the play dough have a longer shelf life. You can omit it, but the dough will not last as long!
-
HOW TO
Mix Together
• 1 1/4 cup of all-purpose flour
• 1/3 cup of fine salt
• 2 tablespoons of cream of tartar
• 2 tablespoons coconut oil 
Add
• 3/4 cup of boiling water (I mix in food coloring to water prior to heating water up in microwave).
-

node.text:
This acorn activity is a fun way to reuse items and create a fun and interactive STEAM experience at the same time! 🙌 If your kiddos are like mine, and love to fill their pockets up with fallen acorns this time of year, 🍂 then they will have so much fun pairing it up with a fun marble-like run. 🤗 Head to my stories for the strong double sided tape that we use for projects like this. Plus, read on below for the step-by-step instructions! Save this post so you remember to do it later and share it with a friend who might want to do it too! 💕
-
HOW TO
(1) Wash and dry some plastic bottles from the recycling bin! 
(2) Grown ups to use a sharp knife to create entry and exit points large enough for acorns to go through.
(3) Decorate your bottles with an Autumn theme if you so wish! We kept ours up for several months so it was a nice fall-themed play area!
(4) Use strong double-sided tape to secure the bottles to the wall, angling them perfectly so that the acorn travels from the top to the bottom. 
(5) Place a recycled bin or tray (ours were a mushroom container!) at the base of the acorn run for a "landing zone."
(6) Drop the acorns and watch them fall from the top all the way to the bottom. 
-

node.text:
It’s amazing what can happen if we shift our perspective. ✨ Is it easy to do? 😬 No way! Am I sharing this quote because I think we should raise children that are rude and have no values? NOT AT ALL. 🙅‍♀️ This quote is a great reminder that when we get upset or question our children’s behavior, let’s look at it deeper before we go with a gut reaction and just shut them down. 👌 Let’s look at it deeper to simply understand a possible root of the behavior. And let’s look at it deeper to see the ways we can guide them so they can achieve their goals respectfully. 💪 
-
Share this with a friend who needs to see this too!
-
